_header: A cruel death contrarious to creatures in kind
_description: A personal elegy on a young gentlewoman — seven stanzas rhyme royal

HunEL26A13.First Lines:
HA cruell deeth contrarious to creatures in kyndeHa deeth dispitous
                    who may aduertise…
HunEL26A13.Last Lines:
…Comely kynde and curteis in nobleye of nurtureVernant in alle
                    vertu plesaunt and demure
HunEL26A13.Editions:
Brown,  Carleton Fairchild,
                        ed.  
             Religious Lyrics of the XVth Century.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1939: 241-43.
MacCracken,  Henry Noble. 
             “The Storie of Aseneth.” 
             Journal of English and Germanic Philology
         9 (1910): 224-64: 262-4 (as Epilogue to 367).
